Here's my opinion, there is no mass that passes through an event horizon. Mass can only exist inside and outside of it.
By definition the force of gravity at the event horizon increases your spatial speed to c. No mass exists at the speed of light. You become photon or some other massless boson. On the other side of the event-horizon, suddenly the opposite happens, if you're a photon and manage to somehow get pushed through, then the farther away from the event horizon that you get, the less force of gravity is applied on you, and suddenly you're a photon able to be in a world with mass again, inside the black hole.

The BEST way to explain it is this:

When you throw an object on earth, it gains some distance and falls down to earth. If you throw it hard even harder, it will go to the other side od the earth and sprial in and fall. If you throw it even hard enough, it will go all around the earth and come back to the point you throw it at and will continue to keep in that orbit, and this is called the escape velocity.

The same happens with light. If you shoot a laser at the surface, it bends a certain number of degrees towards earth because of the gravity bending the space around it. If the gravity is very strong like it is on a star, the light will bend so much it will spiral in to go hit the ground on the other side of it. Now if the gravity is so strong like in a blackhole (which is a collapsed star) the light it will go all the way around the blackhole and meet back to the point it was launched at. This is the blackhole event horizon. Any closer to the blackhole, means the light will spiral in, hence the phrase "even light can't escape it"

I've seen in more than one place that you could theoretically survive crossing the event horizon of a sufficiently large mass, but I'm not sure that's true. Time dilation reaches an asymptote around event horizons if I remember correctly. In other words, any matter that reaches an event horizon experiences no time passed relative to anything outside the horizon. That means if a person were to fall into a black hole, whatever part touches the horizon first won't finish crossing it by the time the rest catches up. Therefore, such a person would be flattened against the horizon before crossing, an event I'm reasonably confident would kill you. If there's something wrong with my reasoning, please let me know.

In 9th grade Earth Science, we very briefly learned about black holes, the life cycle of a sun, etc, but we never dove too deeply. It was just "event horizon" and "spagettification", and the doom of our sun billions of years in the future.

I wish I learned about the intensity of black holes in that class, when I was 15. Learning about it now, it's so scary that it's beautiful to me. I'd hear phrases like "They have a black hole for a stomach," or "Our house is a black hole - once something enters, it's gone forever." But I've never known JUST how fucked these things are, and they're REAL. They're OUT THERE.

If we had been shown these videos back in 9th grade, I'd see the universe so differently than I did until I hit about 20 years old.

TL;DR: I wish I were taught how crazy black holes are in school. They're scary but they're real, and that fact can really change your perspective on life

There are a few errors in these that need clarification.
1. You can't see the event horizon, the dark region we see is the shadow region, which is larger than the horizon.
2. The singularity, as far as GR goes, is not a point of infinite density, but a hypersurface where worldlines find their terminus.
3. How soon you would die does NOT depend on the mass. You go from a vague sense of something wrong to vanishing at the singularity in about 0.1 seconds. This entire section of the video is wrong, but the rest of the video is alright.

Hmmm...I would think that some point during a stars collapse the mass of the event horizon exceeds that of the remaining mass in the stars center. At this point the events gravity is stronger
pulling the center mass to the horizon leaving in its wake a vacuum of perfect zero which is your "black hole". Nothing can enter a vacuum of perfect zero and anything colliding with it would be instantly destroyed. As for that matter there is no way to know/prove that the vacuum of space is uniform throughout the universe. Take for example the "Expanding Universe Theory", is the universe expanding or is the vacuum of space declining, both cases would produce the exact same observational results. Which also leads us to the "Big Bang Theory". If the universe expanded from a single point then if you are in some point in space the expansion would appear directional, pointing to the point of origin. On the other hand if in fact the vacuum is declining
THEN it would appear to be expanding in EVERY direction.

Black holes put a new spin on Zeno's paradox.

Paraphrase of Zeno's paradox: A journey is broken up into intervals of distance. Each interval is one half of the remaining distance. The journey is now made up of an infinite number of intervals, so how can it be completed? The answer is that crossing each interval requires only half of the time as crossing the previous interval, so adding up the times to traverse the entire infinite set of intervals is only twice as long as crossing the first interval.

Black holes change the time needed to cross the smaller intervals as the traveler gets closer and closer to the event horizon. If the time dilation makes the time elapsed to cross the next interval take as long as crossing the previous interval, the black hole will evaporate before traveler reaches the event horizon.

This raises the legitimate question of whether anything falling towards a black hole ever actually falls in?

A thoughtful look at black holes.

This might be a short article. I'd like to discuss what happens when a black hole forms. When it happens an isolated region of space is created. Entirely cut off from this universe. A bubble outside the universe connected to our universe by only a point. A point we call a singularity.

First thing first, a point had no dimension. So in order for anything to cross into the interior of the black hole, that thing would need to have been reduced to a mass of zero volume, and become a string of points with no dimension. If this is true nothing enters a black hole except a string of points. Points that have no measurable anything. So clearly a black hole can't destroy matter in this way, by taking away an object's dimensions. Everything getting too close would be reduced to nothingness. Leaving nothing to enter the black hole.

Rule 1…. Nothing can enter a black hole

Secondly, as an object approaches the event horizon of a black hole that object is accelerated to the speed of light at the event horizon. A few things could happen.

The object exceeds the speed of light and crosses the event horizon. But wait relativity says to do that you need an infinite mass, so , were any object to attain the speed of light would instantly fill the universe completely, 100 percent with a homogenous mass. So clearly this can't happen. Nothing but light can travel at the speed of light. Right.
There is also the problem of time slowing down almost to zero near the speed of light and time is equal to zero at the speed of light. Therefore it stands to reason that if an object were going the speed of light time would stop at the event horizon. No more events can occur when time is equal to zero. I.e. you can't go any further and enter the black hole because by definition that would be an event. Which is no longer allowed because time has now stopped. Therefore nothing can ever cross the event horizon and all matter and information trapped by the black hole is at the horizon. Compacted as if pushed against a wall. The wall called the event horizon. As more and more matter is squeezed against the horizon it gets hot.

Very very hot. So hot that jets of radiation spew from the poles in both directions.

In conclusion, nothing can enter a black hole. By definition almost, the event horizon. Should more aptly be named the No Event Horizon. For there all time stops. And nothing can ever cross, in, or out. Because 4 dimensional things… cannot become zero dimensional points.

Black hole explained, Imagine a pressure That permeates the entire universe, even before anything exist, Some called this pressure dark matter or the field but the original name was the Aether, Now imagine 2 physical objects some distance apart from each other within this pressure call Aether, space or the void,
These 2 objects will have an infinite pressure point from all directions, except form between each other, Because there will only be a finite amount of pressure between 2 objects,
This low pressure point between 2 objects will cause them to accelerate towards one another, or better put towards the lowest pressure point between each other, As they move towards each other, the pressure drops, low and low, which is the cause of acceleration, The low pressure points between two objects is also in truth a black hole, It isn’t a hole, just a low pressure point. Between every Physical object, small or big, is a finite Low pressure points, now imagine a galaxy with millions of stars and planets and a low pressure point between every one of them, and in the center of this cluster will be the lowest pressure point called a black hole, That’s why you have a supermassive black hole in the center of every galaxy,

This video made one crucial mistake, which was, claiming that you would see the entire future of the universe when you fall in. You wouldn't. This is a common myth. It's based around the fact that gravitational blueshifting/time dilation becomes infinite at the event horizon. The problem is, you're also subject to regular doppler redshifting from your motion as you fall in, and you're falling away from everything at the speed of light at that point, and the 2 effects cancel each other out.

Technically, we can escape from below the event horizon.

The event horizon is the radius at which the escape velocity (A.K.A. the orbital speed at which an object will never come back to the object) is the speed of light (c = 300000 km/s). So if your spaceship has an engine powerful enough, you could put yourself on a suborbital trajectory which gets above the event horizon. From there, you can propel yourself above escape velocity and go back home. You could also be in a stable orbit below the event horizon, since the circular orbit velocity is slightly lower than the escape velocity.

Even approaching an event horizon, you need to be going at relativistic speeds. The tidal forces exerted on your infinitely flat corpse would be so strong that it wouldn't just spaghettify your body into atoms, but into subatomic particles and, right next to the event horizon, photons. When the photons that were your body reach the event horizon (the ones that do anyway; most will actually be shot off in other directions), the black hole's velocity shifts an infinitesimal amount in what was your direction, and every photon that reaches the event horizon contributes in an infinitely small way to the overall volume of the event horizon.

In this way, certain information about what was left of you is preserved at the event horizon because the photons will cause infinitesimally small shifts in the location, vector, mass and 'rotation' of the event horizon (it doesn't actually rotate, but because of how it warps space it seems like it does).

For all physical intents and purposes, for everything except perhaps certain fields, there is no "inside" of a black hole, nor is there a central singularity. Everything inside the area of an event horizon is an average of its density. It has to be; gravity is so intense there, time stops.

So, how can a black hole "spin", if it has no motion because there is no time because gravity is so intense? (Motion requires time; black holes stop time in their volume.)

Space is warped around the black hole in such a manner that would correspond to its spin, were the area within the event horizon effected by time, and thus be capable of motion. Because it cannot itself rotate, what would correspond to its rotational inertia is expressed as space warped in such a way (the ergosphere) that it seems like the event horizon is rotating, up to the point of causing oblateness in the event horizon. Don't be fooled though: it isn't actually rotating.

It seems obvious to me that nothing has ever gotten past the EH since the universe began, but the EH has grown past the previously accreted particles as the proximate mass increases the EH radius past previous accretions.  Nothing gets past the EH, because the relative rate of time (with respect to the ordinary (external) rate of time in space) slows as you approach the EH, until at the EH, the relative rate of time is effectively zero.  This also resolves the holographic paradox, because all of that information IS at the surface of the "moment".  BTW, I suspect that information is also a function of time.  Anyway, if you slice a black hole in half, to view the cross-section, it would appear as an onion (cut thru its equator), with the oldest objects near its original EH, and all subsequent accumulation stuck at its respectively greater radii of EH by the relatively zero rate of time, so the newest in-fall is forever stuck at the current EH by its zero relative rate of time.  This model does not as easily reveal to me what happens to the original content of the iron core (corpse).  It might be effectively unfrozen in the zero G center of the BH as mass accumulates outside, leading to a larger and larger zero G, thawed time core.

Doesn't the nature of hawking radiation imply that the material in the singularity becomes the pair of particles at the event horizon?  It can't lose mass if those particles at the event horizon were never part of the singularity's mass, it would be gaining mass instead. I don't think a black hole would ever die. 3/18/2020/rev. 3/22/2020: W Rusty Lane's theory of Black Holes: Black holes are formed in the traditional way--a star super novas and collapses within itself. A black hole is defined by its mass as well as its centripetal acceleration. The area around the black hole or its event horizon is accelerating beyond the speed of light so that light itself, its photons are accelerated beyond the speed of light. No light can be emitted from the black hole. When you scientists contemplate black holes you tend to over think the whole issue. My theory is that black holes are reverse space tornadoes which suck in matter at the event horizon and spew it out at the vortex of the black hole. Most scientists think that the space-time continuum at the bottom of the black hole is so warped that a cone is formed and at the very tip of the cone there exists the singularity. I don't agree with that. I think the black hole forms a vortex just like a tornado which is spinning and since matter is neither created nor destroyed it merely spews matter out at the vortex just like a reverse tornado. No one has ever seen into the bottom of a black hole and who's to say that it doesn't have a vortex or "worm hole" to another part of the universe. The universe contains a finite amount of "stuff" or matter and matter is neither created or destroyed; it is merely transported to another part of the universe. In this way all the mathematics still work and Einstein's theory is proved and is still valid. I believe this is how new stars are born and that matter and energy are conserved. If the black hole is spewing out more matter than it consumes then it will gradually grow smaller and smaller until it finally disappears. Thus you can validate the shrinking of black holes.
At the event horizon the matter is accelerated to the speed of light. Most scientists will agree that the theory of relativity means that at or near the speed of light that time is distorted. In order for you to exist in time you have to have height, width and depth or be three dimensional in time. For me time is the fourth dimension. If you have no height, width or depth then you do not exist in time or are the null set. If you have height, width and depth and do not have any time then you do not exist or are the null set. To me there was only one singularity. Time equaled zero and space equaled zero at the moment before the big bang. When the big bang happened then time began as well as did space. The space expanded over time and is still expanding today. This is the main reason I do not believe there exists a singularity at the very bottom of a black hole. When things (matter) become accelerated to the speed of light time gets distorted and begins to slow down. That's why scientists say an observer looking at a space ship approaching the event horizon of a black hole never seems to go into the black hole; they merely slow down as they approach the speed of light. As matter is accelerated to the speed of light it falls into the black hole or crosses the event horizon where t=0 or time is equal to zero. I believe that's what scientists mean by the firey ring around the event horizon, the acceleration of matter to the speed of light. Inside the black hole time is zero or becomes the null set. If a particle having height, width and depth and time is equal to zero then it ceases to exist. I do not believe that space ever is equal to zero inside a black hole. Space itself approaches infinity so space never equals zero as scientists think. In order to have a singularity, time would have to be equal to zero as well as space would have to be equal to zero. I think it's just the reverse. As the particle inside the black hole begins to de-accelerate it falls out the other end of the black hole and becomes a particle again as it loses momentum and is spewed out the vortex of the black hole. Another view has the particle when its time is equal to zero it becomes an anti-particle and settles to the bottom of the black hole where it becomes entangled with a positive particle and that is emitted through the vortex of the black hole. Then the anti-particle is emitted as part of the Hawking radiation. I believe in the conservation of matter and energy, that neither is created or destroyed. I simply cannot fathom that a black hole contains a singularity; it just doesn't make sense.
Now you may ask, what about the mass of the object, the black hole? I think the mass of the black hole only affects the event horizon in that the mass causes the centripetal acceleration to approach and surpass the speed of light. As the neutrons become packed so tightly together, time is equal to zero, space begins to approach zero as the neutrons approach infinity. Space only approaches zero but is never equal to zero because there is a tiny bit of space between the tightly packed neutrons, thus no singularity. As the matter passes into the black hole some of it makes its way through the tightly packed neutrons and is ejected out the vortex or worm hole at the bottom of the black hole. It probably somehow adds neutrons to the particles and makes up new atoms as it is ejected out of the vortex.

It's thought that if you were to enter a black hole, you'd undergo something called Spaghettification. Interestingly, this process happens anywhere where there's a centre of gravity to fall towards. If you dropped four moving objects towards the surface of a planet, the arrangement of the objects would eventually resemble a diamond, because gravity would pull hardest on the centre of the falling objects' mass. This doesn't affect humans very much, although you'd obviously burn up before you reached the ground. However, in black holes, that gravity is so strong that your extremities would snap taut, and then begin being stretched until they broke at each joint. Your ankles would be the first to go, then your knees, hips, and eventually you'd be snapped in half at the waist like dry spaghetti, hence the name. You would become pasta; gory, bloody and doomed, but basically pasta.

What science and astronomy calls a black hole mass is in reality a hole or void where no mass can exist. The common description defies all gravitational  concerns and theories.. If we look at say a twenty five star conglomeration of stars orbiting a common point in space, that point in space in which all of those stars is orbiting will not have an iota of mass at its point mass center. This because all of the stars would be exerting an equal gravitational force on that point. In a galactic framework with billions of stars orbiting a common point mass center you have the exact same effect a void in space where no mass can exist. only much larger than the point mass center of twenty five stars. The radiation directed toward this void is sent around it towards the poles of the galaxy and in some cases isb seen as streams of radiation being emitted for billions of miles up and downward from these polar axis.

I'm not a Physicist but I really like these things out there! Modern physics teach us that gravity is not some tractive force, it simply results from the forced movement of bodies onto geodesics, as created by the distortion of space. We let something out of our hands and it falls down as it follows the course of an invisible "slide"/"escalator" that surrounds us. The slide begins where the distortion of space begins and ends at the center of the Earth. It has a funnel shape so ... The slope of the slide will make the object fall down accelerating accordingly. If an object on any planet moves from the surface upwards at an initial velocity equal to the escape velocity then it can climb the "slide" until it escapes from the funnel. In the case of the black hole, however, the distortion is such that the slide is rather convex like an elliptical / circular disk so that even the light is rotated inside the convex slide, never able to escape. If the slide had not been convex, then we would have seen the light sometime ... because there is no force preventing it from escaping ... it is probably the shape of the slide!

Black Holes

Don't let the name fool you: a black hole is anything but empty space. Rather, it is a great amount of matter packed into a very small area - think of a star ten times more massive than the Sun squeezed into a sphere approximately the diameter of New York City. The result is a gravitational field so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape. In recent years, NASA instruments have painted a new picture of these strange objects that are, to many, the most fascinating objects in space.

￼

Intense X-ray flares thought to be caused by a black hole devouring a star. (Video)

Watch the Video


The idea of an object in space so massive and dense that light could not escape it has been around for centuries. Most famously, black holes were predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity, which showed that when a massive star dies, it leaves behind a small, dense remnant core. If the core's mass is more than about three times the mass of the Sun, the equations showed, the force of gravity overwhelms all other forces and produces a black hole.

￼

A video about black holes.

Watch the video


Scientists can't directly observe black holes with telescopes that detect x-rays, light, or other forms of electromagnetic radiation. We can, however, infer the presence of black holes and study them by detecting their effect on other matter nearby. If a black hole passes through a cloud of interstellar matter, for example, it will draw matter inward in a process known as accretion. A similar process can occur if a normal star passes close to a black hole. In this case, the black hole can tear the star apart as it pulls it toward itself. As the attracted matter accelerates and heats up, it emits x-rays that radiate into space. Recent discoveries offer some tantalizing evidence that black holes have a dramatic influence on the neighborhoods around them - emitting powerful gamma ray bursts, devouring nearby stars, and spurring the growth of new stars in some areas while stalling it in others.
One Star's End is a Black Hole's Beginning
Most black holes form from the remnants of a large star that dies in a supernova explosion. (Smaller stars become dense neutron stars, which are not massive enough to trap light.) If the total mass of the star is large enough (about three times the mass of the Sun), it can be proven theoretically that no force can keep the star from collapsing under the influence of gravity. However, as the star collapses, a strange thing occurs. As the surface of the star nears an imaginary surface called the "event horizon," time on the star slows relative to the time kept by observers far away. When the surface reaches the event horizon, time stands still, and the star can collapse no more - it is a frozen collapsing object.

￼

Astronomers have identified a candidate for the smallest-known black hole. (Video)

Watch the Video


Even bigger black holes can result from stellar collisions. Soon after its launch in December 2004, NASA's Swift telescope observed the powerful, fleeting flashes of light known as gamma ray bursts. Chandra and NASA's Hubble Space Telescope later collected data from the event's "afterglow," and together the observations led astronomers to conclude that the powerful explosions can result when a black hole and a neutron star collide, producing another black hole.
Babies and Giants
Although the basic formation process is understood, one perennial mystery in the science of black holes is that they appear to exist on two radically different size scales. On the one end, there are the countless black holes that are the remnants of massive stars. Peppered throughout the Universe, these "stellar mass" black holes are generally 10 to 24 times as massive as the Sun. Astronomers spot them when another star draws near enough for some of the matter surrounding it to be snared by the black hole's gravity, churning out x-rays in the process. Most stellar black holes, however, lead isolated lives and are impossible to detect. Judging from the number of stars large enough to produce such black holes, however, scientists estimate that there are as many as ten million to a billion such black holes in the Milky Way alone.
On the other end of the size spectrum are the giants known as "supermassive" black holes, which are millions, if not billions, of times as massive as the Sun. Astronomers believe that supermassive black holes lie at the center of virtually all large galaxies, even our own Milky Way. Astronomers can detect them by watching for their effects on nearby stars and gas.

￼

This chart shows the relative masses of super-dense cosmic objects.

Read the full article


Historically, astronomers have long believed that no mid-sized black holes exist. However, recent evidence from Chandra, XMM-Newton and Hubble strengthens the case that mid-size black holes do exist. One possible mechanism for the formation of supermassive black holes involves a chain reaction of collisions of stars in compact star clusters that results in the buildup of extremely massive stars, which then collapse to form intermediate-mass black holes. The star clusters then sink to the center of the galaxy, where the intermediate-mass black holes merge to form a supermassive black hole.

Dear Whoever reads this,

I think I just came to a mental breakthrough on the topic of black holes. So we know gravity bends space, and we know that every black hole takes in energy and matter but doesn't let any out minus hawking radiation.

Where does all of this go?

White holes seems to be the logical answer, and I think it is. but so far mainstream science hasn't found evidence for their existence. And I think that's because white holes are produced in the exact opposite way: Space expanding to such lengths that instead of forcing all of the information into a singularity, there is essentially a rip in space that would be torn at the smallest possible scale.

As far as I'm concerned, this sort of tearing can only exist as a result of our current universal expansion/acceleration, and the Universe accelerating outward reminds me how gravity accelerates things towards it's center

okay so get ready to have your mind blown: Let's say you get sucked into a black hole. Your atoms and every other particle is taken into the singularity... and I believe it is stored. Once it's stored the only way to release it is to, like I said, have the opposite of a singularity or an expansion driven tear into spacetime, expel all of info in every direction.

The only point where spacetime could be stretched enough to rip it would be in 10^100^100 years or something.. but by then the entire existance would uniformly rip in all places. The ensuing matter explosion would essentially be a big bang in every possible place at once.

So that's how the Universe started. Our existence is a result of a White Bang in a previously existing universe that expanded itself to heat death. Why is it expanding?

Gravity and Antigravity (The repelling, accelerating force) are like hills and valleys in a space time world. Each valley is a gravity field. Each hill is an Antigravity field. Both are relative, that is to say you can't have 2 hills without a valley, or 2 valleys without 3 hills. All of that empty space is expanding, for the same reason that all of the occupied space is contracting. They are simply products of the same phenomena. The more empty the space, the greater the expansionary force is. This is why the spaces between stars aren't overcome with Antigravity, while on a galactic scale, gravity usually is overcome by Antigravity.

Now for the rest of the theory to work there is an assumption to be made that the information held in limbo after being taken by a black hole and before being expelled by a White hole, is a different dimension on a scale smaller than plank scale. This is "where" the 3rd dimension aka our dimension resides, but it's literally every where. When a White Bang happens, all the white holes expand. I'm not sure if they touch but if they do, the dimension they come from envelops our heat death 3rd dimension, making the entire universe that dimension.

At this point it goes one of two ways: a loop or a ladder. That dimension is either a parallel 3rd dimension... and this loops on forever, making the Universe infinite and with no causality, because while it explains what will happen and what has happened, it doesn't explain how the cycle began. Not very satisfying

Or, we are on a ladder, having come from a different dimension lower than ours through the same physics, only to be overtaken by the next dimension with the same physics.. and so on, either forever evolving higher, or coming to a final destination in death, rebirth, and evolution.

So the "Big Crunch" is actually a thing or is it just a theory?

For decades, black holes were thought to form when a massive star collapses under its own gravity to a single point in space – imagine the Earth being squished into a ball the size of a peanut – called a singularity. So the story went, an invisible membrane known as the event horizon surrounds the singularity and crossing this horizon means that you could never cross back. It's the point where a black hole's gravitational pull is so strong that nothing can escape it.

The reason black holes are so bizarre is that it pits two fundamental theories of the universe against each other. Einstein's theory of gravity predicts the formation of black holes but a fundamental law of quantum theory states that no information from the universe can ever disappear. Efforts to combine these two theories lead to mathematical nonsense, and became known as the information loss paradox.

In 1974, Stephen Hawking used quantum mechanics to show that black holes emit radiation. Since then, scientists have detected fingerprints in the cosmos that are consistent with this radiation, identifying an ever-increasing list of the universe's black holes.

But now Mersini-Houghton describes an entirely new scenario. She and Hawking both agree that as a star collapses under its own gravity, it produces Hawking radiation. However, in her new work, Mersini-Houghton shows that by giving off this radiation, the star also sheds mass. So much so that as it shrinks it no longer has the density to become a black hole.

Before a black hole can form, the dying star swells one last time and then explodes. A singularity never forms and neither does an event horizon. The take home message of her work is clear: there is no such thing as a black hole.

The paper, which was recently submitted to ArXiv, an online repository of physics papers that is not peer-reviewed, offers exact numerical solutions to this problem and was done in collaboration with Harald Peiffer, an expert on numerical relativity at the University of Toronto. An earlier paper, by Mersini-Houghton, originally submitted to ArXiv in June, was published in the journal Physics Letters B, and offers approximate solutions to the problem.

Experimental evidence may one day provide physical proof as to whether or not black holes exist in the universe. But for now, Mersini-Houghton says the mathematics are conclusive.

Many physicists and astronomers believe that our universe originated from a singularity that began expanding with the Big Bang. However, if singularities do not exist, then physicists have to rethink their ideas of the Big Bang and whether it ever happened.

"Physicists have been trying to merge these two theories – Einstein's theory of gravity and quantum mechanics – for decades, but this scenario brings these two theories together, into harmony," said Mersini-Houghton. "And that's a big deal."

First comment ever on youtube... bit fan of kurzgesagt (!), but one thing is wrong in this episode. When falling into a black hole you cant "see the rest of the universe fast forward, kinda like seeing into the future", since if you are accelerating up to the speed of light, all the light going towards you from the rest of the universe will have a harder time catching up to you, causing redshift, thus in "time" (pun intended) you will not be able to see what is happening in the rest of the universe as we can't see wavelengths longer than the colour red. Even if you could see shorter wavelengths with some gadget, at the time you are near the event horizon the majority of all photons coming from the universe (i.e. from the "future") will never reach you as you are travelling too fast. Thought or comments, or if you wanna correct me, please do, here to learn!

Huge misconception. You do not need to travel faster than the speed of light to escape a black hole. You need a greater ESCAPE VELOCITY. meaning that if there is no further force applied, you would need to have an initial velocity greater than the speed of light. If you produce a force greater than that of the weight of the object, you can still escape a black hole (you just need a hell of a lot of force).

I appreciate all this fantastic knowledge that you are spreading to the masses, but the Hawking Radiation explanation you have is not quite accurate. It is a bit complex, but here we go:

First off, every particle has its own field and when the field oscillates, it results in a particle. An electron is an oscillation of the electron field. A photon is an oscillation of the photon field etc.

Another key thing to know is that in the presence of a event horizon, different observers disagree about whether the field is in a vacuum state (think of it as the fields with no particles and therefore no energy; although due to uncertainty, there could be fluctuations in the field which result in energy which result in the formation of virtual particles) or not. The equations needed to calculate the behavior of oscillations of fields has to be tweaked in the presence of a horizon in order to abide with the laws of physics and this causes a different view on whether the field is in a vacuum state or not.

Now that we got those ideas out, let’s delve in to Hawking Radiation. So let’s say we have a vacuum state and let’s think of it as just a straight line with different waves (remember that particles act like particles and waves at the same time, so these waves just represent virtual particles which cancel each other out due to matter and anti-matter pairs). Now let’s put the black hole in the center. As the vacuum state passes through the black hole, some of these waves (virtual particles) are getting scattered by the event horizon. Some remain though. On the other side of the blackhole, some of these waves are not present in the field because they were scattered. So the vacuum state is distorted. This vacuum state distortion looks like we have a stew of many particles. An distant observer will see this as radiation being emitted from the black hole.

Now the wavelengths of the Hawking Radiation called the Bregolie wavelengths tell us that there is a quantum uncertainty where these particles are actually located at. So an observer in free fall into the horizon sees the field as still being a vacuum state while a distant one sees it as the blackhole radiating and therefore not in a vacuum state.

Black holes without singularity and systems below the Planck scales
Reference: An observer falling into a black hole observing something that is also falling into a black hole just before it:
If an outside observer never observes an in-falling observer ever fall into the black hole, any particle entering the black hole should feel nothing else to be inside the black hole but only itself; because just before it entered the black hole, everything that was about to enter the black before it froze at the event horizon, so there is nothing inside the black hole but just that particle. This would mean that there would be no singularity.

Second option-Now let’s say that it would feel everything to be normal-that is see its predecessors fall into the black hole and that only those outside observers accelerating away from the black hole see things freezing on the surface of the black hole. For that to happen, when the same observer is moving towards the black hole, observes things going in; but when accelerating away observes things clumping up on the horizon. If that were to happen, every time the observer went back and forth the clumping would freeze and unfreeze.

Third-Or if an outside observer maintaining a constant distance from the black hole is the one that observes the clumping. When the observer moved away, if the things unfroze, entering the black hole; relativistic predictions would be incorrect.

Inside the black hole:
I like to talk about the first interpretation-the violation of the extrapolation of the geometry inside the black hole-that there is no singularity. If we add some definitions to the idea, it looks familiar to a question, we’ve been asking and the incomprehensible answer we’ve been getting.

First, the observer sees no non-virtual particles. However, high energy virtual particles pop into and out of existence frequently. When one of such particle deforms space-time, it forms temporary gravitational influence on the “only one” non-virtual particle-“observer” before shortly ceasing to exist and no more influencing the non-virtual particle. Another virtual particle comes into existence somewhere inside the black hole and temporarily pulls the non-virtual particle in a different direction (could be the same) with different intensity depending on their relative positions. As many virtual particles pop into existence, the particle is pulled around and pulled in some other direction while some virtual particles cease to exist and some other new virtual particles come into existence. The non-virtual particle is pulled around inside the black hole in this field of virtual particles; never quite achieving the influence to escape the black hole. It could be helpful to imagine the idea as a yo-yo being pulled back and forth, allowing the movement in all directions and the intensities to be different.

The same idea can be described in a different way. The space-time inside the black hole is a high energy deformation in the portion of space-time where, as virtual particles pop into and out of existence, powerful gravitational waves move the non-virtual particle around, inside the black hole. The gravitational waves are the result of virtual particles coming into and out of existence, producing different patterns of gravitational strong fields.

Explaining a very similar answer; and amazing consequences
Length below the Planck length leads to answers that there should be black holes everywhere below the Planck length. While that might tell us that we don’t understand it so well, it could very well be telling us a different story this whole time. Maybe the reason systems below the Planck scales give rise to black hole scenarios is because what happens inside a black hole is very similar to what happens inside a Planck length-what happens to space-time.
Below the Planck scale, space-time is not empty and virtual particles coming into existence and going out of existence make up the vacuum energy field, as well accepted. Every point in space-time is stretched, as virtual particles come into existence as the vacuum energy field fluctuation. This is exactly like the first definition we established about what happens inside the black hole. The high energy virtual particles coming into and out of existence inside the black hole, cause gravitational influence because the gravitational waves are localized. Similarly, the virtual particles coming into an out of existence in vacuum field, stretch space-time at a lot of points (theoretically all points) and in a lot of all directions (theoretically all directions), creating the effect observed as Dark Energy. There is one more definition we need to add here. As, the virtual particles inside the black holes come into and out of the existence, the virtual particles coming into and out of existence that make up the vacuum energy field-do so at inside the Planck-scales, let’s say inside the Planck volume. Since, the two phenomenon are extremely similar, that is why we get an answer that there should be black holes below the Planck scales, when we compute the prediction of our theories. But more than being similar, the two phenomena could be two observations of a single phenomenon.

The Hawking Radiation and conservation of information
It could very well be the case that the matter eaten by black holes in our universe appear as virtual particles in space-time outside the black holes; and that explaining why “inside the Planck scale phenomenon” and “inside the black hole phenomenon” are the same thing. Now the way this model can elegantly describe the hawking radiation or quantum tunneling as the property of the particles inside the black holes to appear outside the black holes as quantum vacuum field fluctuations-(the reason such systems are described as quantized at the Planck scales can be better discussed by explaining the Schwarzschild radius); And this does not violate information conservation. And black holes turn out to be converting matter into vacuum energy diluting the energy in our universe.

An unanswered question: revisiting group splitting
All along this time, we did not answer why the particle inside the black hole observes no other non-virtual particle. This idea is described using the splitting of a group; the central idea in this discussion. A black hole has the following property. Before entering the black hole, some matter can interact with each other in space and are described as being in the same system in the “volume neighborhood” or less seriously-space. A black hole can split this system into many systems that cannot interact in the “volume neighborhood”. According to the idea of group reconfiguration, space-time is the geometry of group configurations while volume neighborhood or dimension is one such configuration. However, the particles may interact in “other dimensions or neighborhoods”, and hence appear as virtual particles to each other in the volume neighborhood, and are able to convey gravitational influence as they continue to have defined geometries of group configurations- or less seriously interactions with space-time. According to the evolving dynamics of group reconfiguration, the virtual particles come into existence and cease to exist.

But what happens when all black holes run out of food to eat?
The universe could be left with just vacuum energy field fluctuations with virtual particles popping into and out of existence. Our universe’s geometry to interact in volume-neighborhood could be gone while the energy of our universe (as particles) may continue to interact in other configurations and neighborhoods. Virtual particles may form real particles. The universe could split into different systems or combine with some other system. The universe could lose its quantization as black holes disappear taking away with them the vacuum energy fluctuation making the system continuous. The continuity could be disturbed when something else interacts with our system in a big bang.

I can't stand videos like this that talk in a factual manner, when the fact of the matter is we really have no clue at all if they exist, how they are formed, or anything about them for that latter. All we have is a bit of math stating that they could possibly exist. The math also states that we can find a planet with flying assholes that shit out chocolate treats, but we would never talk about that in a factual way.

In the grand scale, we still don't know very much about the human body, we know less about Earth, even less about our solar system, FAR less about our Galaxy, and next to nothing about our universe. Yet people continually talk in a factual way about things we have no clue about. Now that's not to say that they are wrong, or right, but presentations like this shouldn't be done in a factual way. They should be presented as a "We think", or "This is our hypothesis" not "This is a black hole, we know they exist, and this is exactly how they work".

This is almost as bad as the ones that claim to know exactly what a planet is like because we observed a TINY dip in the light output from a star and assume it's a planet and that said planet rains diamond's. I mean come the fuck on, are scientists that fucking naive?

Even young children are taught (or used to be, who knows what they are taught now with people thinking the earth is flat and shit) that you have a theory, you build a hypothesis around that theory, then you find a way to prove or disprove it. You don't just assume that you're right, that's just daft.

For all we know the center of the galaxy is a Dyson Sphere, or maybe a doughnut? Could be an apple, we have no bloody clue, and odds are, at the rate we're going, we will never find out.

My hypothesis that Dark Matter is not a WIMP, but maybe is a deformation of space-time by which the curvature of space-time alone is the cause of the gravitational effect. Gravity is the consequence of the curvature of space-time. It may be possible that the structure of space-time itself could be warped without the presence of mass. Space-time has been shown to react like a fabric by warping, twisting, and propagating independent of mass. These properties have been proven with observations of gravitational lensing, frame dragging, and now gravitational waves. Fabrics can be stretched, pressured, and/or heated to the point of deformation. Such extreme conditions were all present during inflation, so it is plausible that space-time’s elastic nature could have hit its yield point and permanently deformed. Therefore, if gravity is the consequence of the warping of space-time, and fabrics can be permanently deformed, then a deformation could create a gravitational effect independent of mass. Thus, the unidentified dark "matter" that seems to be so elusive to modern science may not be matter at all but merely warped deformities causing gravitational effects. DM could be a microscopic black hole with no mass at the center...
Prediction: Spacetime's elastic property hits a yield point, so only that part of geodesic's "stretch marks" would remain after inflation stopped. These steep gravitational wells would not follow the inverse square law.

not going to go into detail about the math used in this, since that alone will take up a whole comment, but,
a star develops more and more iron in the core, and when it reaches a critical amount, the mass is too much, and gravity exceeds over the radiation. At that moment, the star collapses under its own gravity, crushing every atom into something so small it's indescribable. If the star is large enough, it'll become a black hole.
we know that gravity works kinda like a spandex sheet - if you stretch it out over something like a few chairs and set something in the center, that's the star. if you take something smaller like a marble compared to a bowling ball, and toss the marble across the spandex a bit away from the bowling ball, the marble will orbit like a planet to its host star. if you replace the bowling ball with something much heavier, like say, a large ball of pure iron, it'll break the spandex. if you take the same marble and spin it the same way, it'll orbit and be pulled by the gravity like spandex surface into the tear in the spandex.
that's how black holes work as well, right? the tear in the spandex is a black hole, and the marble is literally anything that exists. if close enough, it'll be pulled in, and to escape it has to push against the spandex, which is impossible on its own.
so what I'm implying is, the universe is like an ever expanding sheet of spandex, and black holes are the tears in the spandex. physical tears. except, there's no end in the black hole, just a singularity that rips things into nothing, and spews them back out as radiation. not a wormhole, just destruction.
so I'm basically saying the universe is torn because a star becomes too heavy, and physically rips it apart.
probably incorrect but hey, it's fun to speculate.

The reaction that crushes matter into a black hole causes a massive energy shockwave.  The shockwave most likely contains all the information of the lost dimension.  Information isn't lost, it is converted into energy and ejected.  I am sure for each object crushed onto the surface of a black hole [after the black hole has already been created] also causes a smaller shockwave which ejects the information representing the 3rd dimension away from the black hole.  What is left on the surface of the black hole is not a record of all the information about the object, only a record of whatever information was not already ejected.  Energy ejects out of a black hole every time something falls into it, that energy contains an entire dimension's worth of information.  That doesn't prove the holographic principle applies here, it only means black holes are good at distilling and separating information from whatever that information was previously coupled with.

2:39 False. Time doesn't actually behave too differently on either side of the event horizon; it just appears that way to an outside observer.
The reason you appear to turn red at the event horizon before vanishing is essentially because every beam of light bouncing off of you into the outside world has to work harder against the black hole's gravity, and as a result the light is stretched out into infrared, micro-, and finally radio waves.
On the other hand, if you were inside a black hole looking outward, you wouldn't notice any change in the "speed" at which time seems to flow. Seeing into the future as you suggested would require one of two things to be occurring: either (a) the light would have to be traveling backwards in time, which would violate causality, or (b) the fall from the event horizon to the singularity would have to take an arbitrarily long if not infinite period of time, with the victim's perception of time being equally altered to produce the "fast forward" effect--pure nonsense.

Right now, many scientists believe there is one universe, consisting of billions of galaxies, each composed of stars, solar systems, comets, meteors, and other matter. This is not correct. We exist in a multiverse, a cosmos that contains our universe as well as many other universes in space-time. In the center of each universe is a super colossal black hole, a black hole so enormous, it is many magnitudes larger than the super massive black hole that exists in the center of each galaxy.

As you know, matter can neither be created nor destroyed. Matter however, can be converted to energy and vice versa. As stars and their solar systems and space matter are drawn into the super-massive black hole at the center of each galaxy, they are converted to pure energy, and sent out the other side of the super-massive black hole, creating new stars, their solar systems, and space matter. While the old stars are gone, the original energy and matter still remain in the galaxy.

This phenomenon also applies to the super-colossal black hole. A whole universe with all of its galaxies, is drawn into its super-colossal black hole, where it is converted into pure energy and then sent out the other side of the super-colossal black hole (a white hole), creating a new universe. The original universe is gone, and a new universe is born - - the Big Bang Theory -- retaining its original energy and matter.

This activity explains why scientists today wrongly believe galaxies are speeding up, expanding, and getting farther apart forever, whereas they are really being drawn closer to the universe’s (very large) super-colossal black hole at a faster and faster rate, and separating in space in the process. (Drop pepper flakes into a toilet bowl; then flush and watch the flakes separate, getting farther and farther apart as they go faster and faster down the drain -- the Event Horizon.)

Scientists are studying quantum physics and string theory, learning space-time is like a fabric in space that bends to the gravity of objects nearby, affecting the speed of its movement. Albert Einstein was incorrect when he said nothing could go faster than the speed of light. He did not actually know about Dark Matter or Dark Energy -- although there was a hint of it in his equations. Dark Energy, or Gravity Hyper-velocity, can go many times faster than the speed of light thereby making space-time travel possible. Dark Energy is gravitational energy, which bends the fabric of space. Albert Einstein demonstrated how time is relative to the speed of an object in motion. Time almost stops for a person traveling at the speed of light, and that person ages very little compared to a person standing still.

We cannot travel through a black hole because at that great gravitational pressure we would be converted into pure energy and lose our mass. Instead, there is another way to travel through time while keeping our own energy and mass: harnessing Dark Energy and creating wormholes in the fabric of space-time.

You see, the multiverse is nothing more than parallel universes all functioning in unison, in the here-and-now, in layers of one dimension each, like a string. Wormholes will allow us to move instantly to any part of a universe of our choice, and time. Space-time is the same everywhere at once.

The multiverse cycles over and over again by energy and mass conversion, and re-creation, in an enormous sphere with no beginning or end. However, relative time or clock time only moves in the place you are in at the moment. Once you move out of that place in space-time, and return to your original place, your relative time continues at the precise clock time where you left it originally. When you travel at Gravity Hyper-velocity speed or Dark Energy speed, space-time stops or can go backwards. Quantum mechanics has proven that things can be in two places at once.

First of all, I’d like to start with a positive statement concerning the idea of producing short animated stories explaining scientific concepts. The problem of course is to focus on an audience: a public with no scientific background at all (beginners), a public having some scientific background (medium) or a public of scientific expert (not specially in the domain, but having good scientific culture). One idea would be to have a small logo indicating the targeted audience. From the graphical and motion design point of view, I find this video very well done.
However, when it comes to the narrative, I find the explanation a bit hectic with certain elements like talking about life and death of living organisms, such as a human being, not very pertinent. There are, behind the concept of black hole, some philosophical, actually metaphysical issues that would have disserved some attention in this video. Remember, a black hole is not only black because it does not produce any light, it's black because, for the time being, we cannot explain it from a scientific stand point. Another point to remember is that the current estimate of astrophysicists is that the universe is made of a bit less of 5% baryonic matter (the matter we know today, made of electrons an protons), 24% of black matter (the only thing we know is that this matter is different from the baryonic one) and 71% black energy. In addition, Albert Einstein’ theory shows the correspondence between matter an energy (E=mC2). The more we know, the less we know, but what is important is to be conscious that there are a lot of things we don't know.

Rather, it's an amount of mass compressed in a space so small, that the DENSITY becomes nearly Infinite and its gravity becomes so strong, that even light-speed isn't enough to escape it and thus collapses into a black hole. (This is call the Schwazschild Radius)

If there was a Black Hole with truly Infinite Mass, the Event Horizon of that Black Hole would be larger than our Observable Universe (In fact it would be Infinitely big)

Yeah, I disagree with this parts of this interpretation. The event horizon is the point at which time stops. Once you reach the event horizon (note, you can't actually cross it, it can only expand around you, as the asymptotic nature of time approaching the event horizon would mean you'd take infinite years to actually cross it, and the black hole would evaporate before then), that's it. Particles that are in the event horizon are held in stasis because no time is acting on them.
Granted, there is not consensus on this, but I have yet to see any evidence disproving it. Hawking radiation... meh, I disagree with that theory in part as well. You do not need to have particles crossing the event horizon to cause evaporation of a black hole, as the mass necessary to maintain the event horizon at its current state is held outside of the event horizon itself, in very very slow, and very violent descent towards the horizon.

Within the event horizon, I see no reason that there should be a single point that is a "singularity" so much as very very dense matter, that can still take up volume. The reason light can't escape the event horizon isn't because gravity exerts a force on light, and I don't think it's because it stretches out space infinitely. I think that light can't escape, because time is stopped, and since light (like all things) moves as a function of time, it doesn't move once it reaches an event horizon.
Now, the locking doors idea can theoretically generate a similar result, but would require dynamic events outside of time, which.... we have never observed. Oh, the M theorists will tell you about the interaction between a host of different dimensions, but we have not observed proof of any of that. Time stopping is a much simpler and more elegant solution.

Perhaps I am mistaken on an assumption that I have made, but I think my understanding of relativity is accurate on this point. Maybe Hawking is right, but I think they're overlooking the obvious. The fact is, if movement outside of time is impossible, the above theory that I stated holds very strongly, and also explains the conical shapes of radiation released from black holes like nothing else does.

So a few things. Someone please answer if you can.

1. Lets take that impossibly big black hole that was just described, and lets say I took 1 step beyond the event horizon. This thing is so impossibly huge... I could almost accidentally step across it, right? And once I do this, even though I'm still alive and well, and conscious and everything... you're saying I CANNOT turn around and walk back? Like, at all? It seems so strange - this black hole is so big that right at the event horizon, you probably wouldn't even know you crossed! It seems so spooky.... what if you were floating around in space really slowly, then couldn't turn and walk back... you might be really scared, "did I just cross the event horizon? I can't turn back! OMG!"

2. What if you passed the event horizon but someone gave you a rope so they could pull you back? Then what? Gravity doesn't become unbearable for a while, so you could float towards it for some time, and I don't think the rope would snap.

3. What would you actually see once you were at the event horizon, or just crossed? Time works differently there, so you would see the universe in fast forward?? This is so incredible to think about. So you would be able to see all your loved ones - and their children - and their children - and their children... all living, dying, living, dying.... and to them, you would just be a still image? But time is going so fast you might even see stars slowly starting to go out, and the heat death of the universe.... you could see the death of everything within a few minutes. Is this right? You're watching the universe die long after every single person who could ever have known that you even lived, has died.

4. Could civilizations survive even beyond the heat death of the universe, if they cultivated power generated from these black holes?? Imagine that heat death has happened... but black holes are still around. Could an advanced civilization maintain itself using these as a fuel source somehow? I can't imagine what the universe would look like... you'd look up, and there's be no stars on a clear night. Everywhere you look, just total blackness... ah! It just now occurred to me! There'd be no day! Only night, all the time... pure, black, empty, and eternal night. But you're still alive somehow. Utterly alone. And cold. Living in a universe that's already dead... warming yourself next to what remains of a black hole.

I don't quite understand the concept of empty space being filled with millions of pairs of particles and anti-particles popping into existence and annihilating each other. I'm not entirely sure that actually happens. but let's say for the sake of argument that this does indeed happen. why would the event happening on the event horizon decrease the mass of the hole until it radiates away? I mean sure, if the antiparticle "spawns" on the inside and the particle spawns on the outside, then the antiparticle goes to the singularity and destroys a particle, and the particle on the outside escapes as hawking radiation, so the mass of the black hole decreases by the particle's mass, and the mass of the rest of the universe increases by the particle's mass, and thus the law of conservation of mass + energy (matter/energy cannot be created or destroyed, but can only be transferred or transformed). but what if the antiparticle spawns on the outside and the particle spawns on the inside? then the mass of the hole increases by the particle's mass and the universe's mass decreases by the particle's mass. it seems to me that the two events would happen just as often, and would balance out, leaving the black hole's mass stable.

That is a good theory that no one will be around to witness the last black hole "die", but I have another. I believe the universe (both observable and non observable) is an unending loop. We believe the beginning of the universe was the big bang, but my theory says that before that there was a universe. Who knows what state that universe was in, but for some reason, it exploded/imploded. Said universe probably had used up all the resources, or was near that. For one reason or another, there was an explosion that destroyed everything except for the atoms, which were ripped apart. That would have been our big bang, and would have started the universe over. We will most likely have many more"big bangs" to come, and the one we know if probably wasn't the first one, either. Now for the cause of the explosion/implosion. It was most likely an explosion, because it shot out the universe, and an implosion would have done the opposite.I believe it was caused by one of a couple different things: A- millions of stars or black holes self destructing, B- the rubber band theory (I will explain), or C- the universe running out of atoms to fuse in stars.
Rubber Band Theory- my theory on how the universe behaves. It will stretch and stretch until it can't anymore. Then it will snap together, like a rubber band, creating the big bang.
PS: sorry if I stole somebody's idea/theory

Here is my theory of black holes, I was sitting in algebra II one day and we were learning about stuff I already knew so I started to think, my thought revolved around mass and surface area which resulted in profound thought of black holes. Sense I did not have a lot of prier knowledge on black holes it was all hypothesized. So here is my explanation first the idea that a star's core becomes unstable resulting in a collapse were the surface area of the spherical star changed but the mass did not. So then I thought okay what does this mean, I then refereed to a balloon, penny, and a needle. As if the surface of the balloon is the fabric of space and a star is a penny, you take a the balloon you press the penny on the balloon representing gravity and the balloon does not pop, now take the same force but use a needle with the same mass instead the balloon will pop due to the higher concentration of surface area on the balloon. Same concept with the relations of stars to black holes same amount of matter in a star that has a surface area of 7.06 X 10 to the 15 power km and then try to fit that mass into an area of 1 cubic inch< or less, Black holes are literally 3 dimensional spherical holes in the universe. An that take you to another theory of mine that all of the matter in this universe has been transported by a past universe and the matter that was in that universe was transported there by an even older universe and so on.

Two things I want to point out:

1. They didn't mention that one of the "technical" reasons for a black hole being black is not only is it because light is not escaping, but because we are seeing the star "frozen" at the moment of its death.
2. Black holes, technically, don't have "mass" their energy went into warped space, which is a form of energy as we learned in Einstein 101. Essentially, what they leave behind is a fossil, a twisted space, and that energy will keep the space warped for billions of years

Gotta nitpick just a little :)
At 1:35 you point out that to escape a black hole you need to travel faster than the speed of light (which I will be refering to with its constat "c" from now on). This isn't really true. In fact, to our knowledge it is not possible to escape a black hole at all, even if you could travel with a speed greater than c.
The fact that the escape velocity at the border of the event horizon is equal to c is just a mathematical coincidence.
And the reason why you can't escape a black hole once you fell in isn't because you need to travel faster than c, it's because the way out isn't defined. It's like dividing by zero, it just isn't an option.
This is because beyond the event horizon spacetime is so heavily warped that all ways lead into the black hole, straight to the singularity.
Imagine you are trying to go out of your house. You walk out of the door and yet you still walk back inside.

if time dilation increases as you fall in, and if hawking radiation exists, then it seems it must always be the case that you never reach the singularity. This is because from the point of view from the outside, an arbitrarily long period of time would have passed as you fell towards the singularity, but by that time, the black hole would have evaporated. So falling in ends with falling out as hawking radiation. And if you can't fall to the very center for this reason, then nothing can, and singularities can't actually exist.

Also, as you fall in, each shell of in-falling matter is accelerating at a different rate from neighboring shells. The shell in front is always accelerating faster, and the shell behind you always slower. It's the same as saying the tidal force is always increasing, of course. However, if you imagine you're in one of these in-falling layers, the fact that the one in front is speeding up faster and the one behind is slower would be kind of like the same thing as you being motionless and the other layers accelerating away from you--sort of what it would look like to be in a universe with an accelerating rate of expansion as ours appears to be.

There is another explanation as to what happens when you enter a black hole.
Since black hole has a huge mass, it creates a huge distortion of spacetime. When an object is approaching a black hole, the distortion of spacetime in its vicinity gets bigger accordingly as the object gets closer and closer to the black hole. Since the distortion in spacetime increases, the object passes longer distances at any given time, which means the object moves FASTER and FASTER as it gets closer to the black hole. The event horizon is the point where the velocity of the object becomes equal to the speed of light. When the object CROSSES the event horizon, its velocity becomes greater than the speed of light and therefore it goes back in time to moment BEFORE it crossed the event horizon. In short, the moment you enter a black hole, you will immediately find yourself OUTSIDE the black hole. You won't die,. Simply you won't be able to enter a black hole because nature doesn't allow it! This is my own theory of black holes :)

~ The Nature of Black Holes:

I have a theory as to the nature and function of black holes. I lack the mathematical skills to express it in the context of an equation, but from what I have gathered on the subject, it leads me to believe that black holes “exist” to generate and emit what scientists refer to as “dark matter”.

Science has noted that dark matter is what comprises the majority of the “space” in the universe. It could be likened to the ocean, where the galaxies and stars are suspended and float through “time”, witch is an expression of the rate of the decay of matter, as it flows towards the center of the galaxy, only to be swallowed by the hole, and then radiated out as more dark matter.

It seems that the time/space continuum is comprised of the dark matter and energy emitted by all these black holes out there, and that’s what holds it all together. It’s the gravitational compression of the invisible dark matter on visible matter. It is the darkness, compressing the light that creates this reality we perceive through our consciousness. If you removed all the dark matter, all matter would disintegrate. The irony is; it doesn’t really exist at all.

Dark matter and the powerful force it emits is the result of its non-existence. But this “nothing” has volume, and therefore a presence. It is the fluid in witch the galaxies and stars float. It is the force that binds all matter together, right down to the atomic and quantum level.

This could also explain why the universe is observed to be expanding. Black holes, spewing out more dark matter, more “space” for new stars to be born into, more “nothing”, the fabric of the universe.

Ultimately this leads to the question: Would the universe exist if there were no consciousness to perceive it? It’s just something for you to ponder, if you have the time to spare. I'm a philosopher, not a physicist, and any philosophical thought on the matter leads into “infinity”. Perhaps a physicist can check my results.

Those are just some of my thoughts on the "hole" issue.

It's me again! Ms. Scientific Buzzkill here to point out errors in the video. Apologies in advance, etc.

Fortunately, there are only two notable mistakes. However, one of them is a major mistake.

The major mistake: "as you enter the black hole you'll see the world around you speed up". This is 100% false, and it isn't surprising that Shortspeak oopsed on this one because this is an extremely common misperception perpetuated in science fiction (many physicists mix this one up, even). Here are the facts.

While it is true that somepony watching you from a distance will see time appear to slow down for you, the traveller sees no relativistic effects of any kind. Why? It's because you're currently in free-fall. Consider standing on Earth: the pressure from the ground is accelerating you away from the center (the normal force counters the gravitational force). This causes time to pass at a different rate for you—it's not just the gravity making time pass more slowly, but the normal force opposing the gravity that causes you to constantly "accelerate away" from the center of the Earth. That constant acceleration against gravity is what produces the relativistic effects (such as time passing more slowly in a valley than on a mountaintop).

If you were falling into a black hole, it would be possible to see time speed up, but for that to happen you would need to accelerate away from the singularity as you fell in. That acceleration would change your inertial frame of reference and produce the relativistic effects you would typically associate with acceleration. You actually would be aging more slowly than the world around you. If you stood on the surface of a neutron star (forgiving the extreme impossibility), you would also age more slowly and see the universe age more rapidly, but again that's because the surface pressure would be accelerating you. Gravity by itself is always finite and only accelerates you at a finite rate, even for a mass as large as a black hole.

The reason for the disparity in the observer's view and reality is that the appearance of time slowing down for an observer on the outside is strictly an illusionary one. It is not a true relativistic effect. Rather, it's caused by the interference between the gravity of the black hole and the ability for the light of an infalling object to reach your eyes. It's easy to get these confused because people are often taught about relativity using examples that are familiar, such as imagining a clock slowing down as it moves away from you faster and faster because of light propagating more slowly to your eyes. (This is a completely false thought experiment, because the speed of light relative to the viewer doesn't change no matter how fast the object moves.)

Think critically for a moment to confirm this. Nothing slows down because it's approaching a singularity. The same laws apply as with any gravitational mass: the black hole has finite mass, and it accelerates you toward it at a finite rate of acceleration. That can be used to calculate precisely when you hit the singularity, which must occur within a finite period of time. For time to stop you'd have to accelerate to infinite speed, and clearly that never happens. This should provide insight into the fact that the visual appearance is an illusion, rather than actual time dilation.

To sum up: yes, an observer would see you slow down and never enter the event horizon (and consequently, you never end up seeing yourself enter the horizon, either, but that's a much more complicated lesson). However, this is an illusionary effect and, not a true relativistic effect! After accounting for the time it takes light to reach their eyes, the observer would correctly deduce that you had long since passed through the event horizon and struck the singularity. The traveller would see no speed-up of time whatsoever, although the sky would end up getting smashed into a thin line perpendicular to the direction of travel (but again, that's a more complicated lesson).

The second mistake is much more subtle. The circle you see is not actually the true event horizon of the black hole. Black holes appear larger than they are, in some sense due to visual effects; but even when you account for that, the boundary you are looking at represents the photon sphere rather than the horizon. Light that enters the black hole from the outside the black hole won't appear within that boundary because light doesn't change direction on its own, and it was headed into the black hole when it was emitted. However, if you see matter fall into the black hole, it will pass through this boundary and still be visible for a while. That's because light reflecting off of the matter wasn't headed into the black hole when it was reflected. :) That light is headed in the opposite direction, away from the singularity, and until you hit the event horizon that light is still going to reach you (even though light already headed toward the black hole at that point is doomed).

As always, I only nitpick because I love. <3 Keep making great videos!

But if we see the things on the event horizon, then black holes aren't actually (don't appear) black. All the concepts and representations of black holes are drawn in 2D, showing a black circle and different (light) things around it. But if we look at a black hole in 3D, we don't see that black circle. Instead, we see only the things on the event horizon, making black holes not black but rather multi-colored.

There is 1 thing that I've been wondering recently. Where does the hole part of a black hole come from? I mean, the most logical explanation for what a black hole would be would be a clump of matter that is dense enough to prevent light from escaping or that puts light into an orbit around itself. So where does the hole part come from? If I'm indeed correct in my assumption there is no hole. The matter is still there but no light gets emitted. It doesn't mean that it all gets condensed into a single point, just that any light that gets reflected from it can't escape, meaning that the clump of matter is simply invisible to us.

I also think that my idea about light ending up in an orbit would be a very likely explanation. Think about it for a moment. For light to be travelling away form the black hole at the speed of light and reach us it would have to be emitted by us. Otherwise it will be entering and exiting the area around the black hole at an angle, (meaning that it will be going alongside the black hole and have a large chance of ending up in an orbit) or would never reach us because it did a 180 degree bounce. And assuming that the matter in the black hole is near infinite density, it would make it very unlikely for anything more than the occasional particle of light to hit us because it would be very rare for a particle to bounce of the area with actual matter without ending up in orbit.
