Technically for an outside observer a black hole never forms, all of them wait for us to jump in. As stated in this video the motion of an object falling into the black hole is slowed down when observed from a distance, the outside observer never sees the object reaching the event horizon. Same applies to the material forming the black hole, it would take an infinite amount of time for an outside observer to see the formation of an event horizon. So how does the Hawking radiation work then? How can a black hole evaporate if it cannot form in the first place? Infinite time is a long period, there might not be a universe around the black hole, what does the outbound particle go into? Lets think about it. Say a virtual pair forms close to the "would be event horizon". Since the pair creation is outside the event horizon it would take a finite amount of time for the outbound particle to escape the gravity, the inbound particle will be part of all the inbound material whose motion towards the event horizon has been infinitely slowed for the outside observer. After a certain (large but finite) amount of time, we'll have a number of outbound particles having escaped the gravity - the Hawking radiation, and the same number of inbound particles that still have not reached an event horizon. Isn't that a contradiction by itself? Even from the perspective of the point where the virtual pair forms, no matter how close to the "would be event horizon" that formation takes place (and it must be a finitely small distance for the outbound particle to be able to escape into something), it would still take an infinite time for the inbound particle to reach the horizon. Doesn't that contradict the delta(E)delta(t) uncertainty principle? This is where general relativity and quantum mechanics need to work together, but they don't, so how can the Hawking radiation work?

Okay, let's say black holes "follow physics laws" for a second.
1. If we were to believe that black holes have no volume and be a singularity, then we can infer it would have no radius as well (Volume = 0 = 4/3 * pi * radius^2 -> radius = 0).
2. If it applies to Newton's universal gravity law (g = -G constant*Mass/radius^2 * <r>), its gravity force would probably be infinite because it would end up in a division by zero.
3. Since Force = mass * acceleration, no matter how massive an object can be, you'd be accelerating towards the black hole at infinite meters per second.
4. This means that on 0 seconds, you'd go from any velocity (even 0m/s) to infinite m/s towards the black hole.
5. This also means that you'd go inside the black hole instantly, therefore we all would be inside the black hole, and therefore dead in 0 seconds flat.
But you're pretty much alive, just as I am and everyone else in the universe we know of their existence. This could mean two things:

A. We're inside a hyper massive black hole, with the mass of the whole universe, and the time dilation is so big that the ripping process might also be extremely slowed down, maybe even stalled, and some sort of gravitational interaction is what makes time happen. I don't think this makes too much sense even if I could have explained properly.

B. The most logical explanation to me is that maybe black holes don't slowly collapse in a singularity, but they reach a point in which they can become stable and stop contracting, just like neutron stars do. However, black holes' are small enough (they have a radius less than their Schwarzschild's radius) to exert enough gravity so that light cannot escape. This would mean that there should be a force we don't know about that somehow is able to overcome the gravity force.
This could mean that if black holes get extremely amounts of not-dense materials, the gravity force it would exert would start to weaken since the radius would get bigger in a faster rate than mass would do, maybe to a point in which light could escape back again. This would probably release enormous amounts of energy, which could may be comparable to very small quasar's?

Black Holes are theoretical nonsense used to prop up the Standard Model. They're just as fanciful (ie - made up) as Neutron Stars (which violate Nuclear Chemistry's Island of Stability law), Dark Matter, Dark Energy and Virtual Particles. The only thing we CAN say is that radio astronomers see highly energetic objects in deep space. Given that plasma discharges in both a glow and non-glow matter (corroborated through countless laboratory experiments with plasma), the simplest answer is that the objects we call black holes are merely non-glow discharge plasma phenomena.

At 2:40 it's mentioned 'you can watch the rest of the universe in fast forward'.
This is a detail I find mostly neglected, but this time you guys even included this aspect.
What I think actually happens is, you see the universe end before you even ever get beyond the event horizon.
Matter doesn't fall in, but 'freezes' just before it enters, preventing a black hole from ever growing.

Relativistic effects already take place on earth, the sun and a lot more near neutron stars.
Continuuing on that, while a star is collapsing into this 'black hole', time dialation is already starting to do it's work.
When there is 99,99...% of the mass inside the swarschild radius, time dialation has the same effect of 'freezing'.
This prevents black holes from ever forming in the first place, instead it's the creation of a 'frozen star', frozen in time.

Having no event horizon ever forming, prevents all sorts of complex problems and attempts for solutions. Like, but not limited to: the information paradox, hawking radiaton / evaporation, the switch between a time-like / space-like interpretation, the so-called firewall, etc.

4:44 Explain to me this; If empty space is (instead of empty) equal and opposite particles popping into existence and destroying each other, then this doesn't explain why black holes lose mass. At this point in the video, you show 1 particle (pink) entering the black hole, while the other (green) escapes it. Why then does it lose mass? if these particles were equal and opposite, then roughly the same amount of positive ones would escape as negative ones, destroying each other, and resulting in a neutral. The same goes for the ones entering, there's no reason for it to lose mass due to hawking radiation if these particles destroy each other. If it's something as neutral as empty space, then why is the black hole actively losing mass/energy, when it could by all reason be gaining it for the same reasons (or both at an equal rate).

Here is my theory for black holes, that they convert mass into negative mass, so basically if you have one atom that collapses in on itself, it creates an empty pocket of space equal to it's mass. All you have to do now is know how matter seeks to fill a lack of matter (like how air floods a room that previously had none) and there's the explanation behind it. The hole keeps growing bigger when it absorbs matter because mass gets converted into space as it passes through the "edge". It's like polygons in a video game getting turned inside out, if you've ever looked out of the inside of a polygon, you won't see the polygon itself.

I hope in the second half the actual appearance of the black hole will be clarified. Firstly there is no event horizon, only an apparent horizon. They more or less stated that though in very different words. There is no definite point of no return. Secondly light is warped and bent as it enters this apparent horizon. Light will reflect off partices leading up to the singularity, making it appear as though everything behind the singularity is skewed to a single point. As no light can escape the singularity except at its poles (as in quasars) you won't see a light source, but you definitely won't see a literal black hole either.

When time runs quicker for an object, the object becomes smaller because of length contraction. So when time runs slower, the object turns bigger.
When you look from a satellite to earth, clocks on earth run slower then they'd run when you looked at them when you were on earth surface. Hence earth measures a tiny fraction bigger watched from space, then what it would measure when you are on earth's surface.
Now put this into extremes. On the event horizon of a black hole, time practically almost stops. So looked from space a black hole looks a lot larger then when it would look when you were on top of its horizon. So when you actually were on that horizon, it would be extremely small. Could it be so small that it actually is the singularity? That would mean, the event horizon is how the singularity looks seen from space.

I believe there's something called the photon sphere or photon radius that you forgot to mention and is pretty interesting. The photon sphere (google it) is located farther away from the event horizon and when an incoming photon tangent to the sphere approaches it can get bound and travel many times around the black hole before either collapsing into the black hole or gets free. So you can pretty much look at a black hole and see you're face smushed around the photon sphere.

To be more specific about the nature of the "phantom" particles that exist.

If they were simply matter-antimatter particles the black hole wouldn't get less massive because antimatter has positive mass , so this isn't the case.
To have the decrease of mass of the black hole the particle that gets absorbed should have negative mass , in the sense of negative energy not opposite charge.

So, seeing that black holes would most likely last well into the heat death of the universe, and when they die they release a massive wave of heat, and whatever matter was inside them at the moment; couldn't it be possible that the Big Bang was a super-super-massive black hole? When all that's let of the universe is black holes, then the only thing that could hypothetically happen would be that they eventually get closer due to their strong gravity, and when the black holes collide, they get stronger (I assume). So this would mean that eventually be it trillions or trillions upon trillions of years, there would be one large black hole. Once this super-super-massive black hole dies from hawking radiation it would explode in one unimaginatively large tidal wave of force, and carry with it all of the matter it had inside of it. This is only my "hypothesis" if you could call it that, but it seems the most logical explanation for the Big Bang, at least to me.

I've watched several videos on black holes here on YouTube, and there's one big question i have:
Can anything really enter a black hole?




It's my understanding that space-time is bent around the black hole in a way so you slow down from an outside perspective, and from your perspective the universe seems to fast-forward, AND the black hole eventually evaporates. As you get closer, time gets faster and faster, and at the horizon all of existence happens at once. But if the BH will disappear in a finite time, it will always disappear before you enter it.
So from an outside perspective everything that has come close enough to a black hole will be almost suspended just above the horizon, never touching it (invisible thanks to red shift), until the BH has disappeared, far in the future. It makes no sense to me to talk about entering a black hole. I've tried to find answers, but have not found it yet.

Hawkin radiation is failed concept.Its a mess of contradictions.
1. Most scientist including hawkin say no events can ever take place, no matter - antimatter annihilation can take place because theres simply no time.
- Even events could take place, matter-antimattter annihilation will produce energy that can not escape faster than speed of light with no time at all. Because energy is essentially mass, even if entire singularity turns into energy, it will still have its old mass.

2. Entirety of hawkin radiation is based on the fact that particle-antiparticle pairs that are randomly spawned by empty space itself will spawn in such configuration that ONLY the antimatter particle falls in and "reduces" singularity mass (which it wont because energy of annihilation cannot escape it and contributes to mass).
- Theres an equal chance of the particle pair to be spawned in exactly opposite way, only contributing to mass while antiparticle flyes away.
- Particle pairs spawn and fly in very specific way that makes it nearly impossible for them to not hit each other.
- Particle pairs spawned in any configuration close to event horizon would require to have enough energy to fly at the speed of light for it to be able to escape the pull of gravity so in most cases pair of particles will fall in. What that does it also increases the mass of black hole. Even though particle and antiparticle mass would normally zero-out, the energy of their annihilation can not escape from event horizon.
In the end that means it doesnt matter which part of the particle-antiparticle pair falls in and how "lucky" black hole is for very specific configuration of these to spawn, black hole will only gain from that exchange.

Why would the energy be "lost" in the process?

It is a common misconception that when looking at ta black hole one sees a black sphere. Funny, just few seconds after claiming this, You also say that what we see is a singularity. This is correct. It's just a singular dot. Mathematically, check Schwarzschild solution, and You'll see that at the black hole's horizon, time becomes space, and space becomes time; time stops moving, and also there are no spatial movements either. The entire black hole region inside the horizon has "slipped out" of the universe. It didn't leave a hole behind: it left nothing behind. Light bends around that point creating unusual patterns due to gravitational lensing, mostly rings, in a spherical pattern. Cheers.

The division by zero comparison is utterly wrong. It's not that we don't "know" what something divided by zero is. It's simply an undefined term. Again, it's a term that hasn't been defined. Not something we don't know – it's something that WE. HAVE. NOT. DEFINED. It's like saying we don't know what a Fjagurtamysrl is and acting like we can some day discover if we try hard enough – it doesn't make sense. You CAN just define what "1 / 0" is, there's no problem in that; the problem is that you cannot define it in any MEANINGFUL way so that it's consistent with other algebraic rules and that's why we simply leave it undefined.
